title: Does anyone know this one?
content:
Hi all,

Take a look at [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20100916224347/http:/www.robinkanters.nl/sample.png) image. Anyone an idea?

I don't think it's Helvetica, although that was my first idea.

There probably has been some manipulation to the text, so an exact match isn't likely.

TIA, Robin
author: Robbinski12

comments.content: Link is working but there is no image.

Ah, i see... Filezilla sais filesize is 0...

Uploading again now...

EDIT: Works now :)

Sorry for the double post, but I just realized that this isn't Myriad Light... It's a Helvetica, the closest I can get to it is with a Helvetica Neue LT Std using the '35 thin'-variant at a 41,64 pt. Then a 164% vertical scale and 135% horizontal scale. Tracking at 20 and small caps. That's what I use instead of the sample and it looks like [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20100916224347/http:/www.chalk-webdesign.nl/headertxt.gif).

Robin

It really is Myriad Light. ;p

Kind regards,  
Martijn van Berkel

<cite>"the closest I can get to it is with a Helvetica…"</cite>  
Dude, you might want to go see an optician. No offense but huh?

The sample you submitted is not Helvetica—it’s Myriad. Lets take a look at some of the details.

This one is yours:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100916224347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Picture5_6161.png)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100916224347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mcad_5753.png)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100916224347im_/http:/typophile.com/files/helv_5137.png)

The first of my samples is a slightly more extended version of Myriad. The second is Helvetica Neue.

Pay special attention the capital G, C, S, the @ symbol and even the capital B and K.

Do you now agree that your submitted is Myriad?

Mikey :-)
Myriad comes in regular, condensed, and semicondensed. That looks like the semi-condensed light.
